title: Wireless furniture for phones
intro: Remember to subscribe to the podcast version !
this_week_question: What do modern phone batteries contain? Is it...
a) nickel b) lithium c) lead-acid
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: things that can be used together
(here) someone or something that is very old-fashioned and no longer useful or effective
furniture with built-in technology which allows you to charge your phone
part of something, and not separate from it
modern equipment and machines that can operate without wires
(informal phrase) don't expect something to happen anytime soon
things that a piece of equipment can do
allows the user of a gadget to change the battery

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Rob... Neil ...and I'm Neil. Hello.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Hello, Neil! Now, Neil, could I borrow your phone charger? My phone's just died.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Er... I don't think my charger is compatible with your phone. Compatible means when you can use things together… I'm afraid there'll be no status updates for you today then Rob.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Oh dear. I can't believe it's run out of power already.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, you shouldn’t have bought a state-of-the-art phone – it's a big drain on the battery.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: State of the art means something that has the newest ideas and features, like my phone. So I should have stuck with a dinosaur like yours, eh, Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And dinosaur here means something that is out-dated. You can laugh at my phone, but it's got plenty of battery life left – unlike yours!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Hmmm... OK, well, I might just pop out and ask if someone's got the same charger…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Stay where you are. We're recording a programme! And today's show is… you guessed it… all about phones!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: That's right, Neil. And we're also talking about wireless furniture …

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Pardon?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Yes, furniture with built-in wireless charging technology - like a coffee table. Built in means the technology is included as part of the table. So you just pop your phone on the table, and technology does the rest!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Magic! And wireless technology is the way mobile phones work using radio waves to send and receive data. So that's what we need - a desk with a built-in charging spot for both our phones! But would it be compatible for both of them?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, that's an excellent question - and I don't have the answer. But can you tell me the answer to this: What do modern phone batteries contain? Is it...

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, lead-acid sounds dangerous... so I think it's either nickel or lithium. I'll go with lithium.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK, well, we'll find out if you're right or wrong later on. But now let's listen to journalist Daisy Buchanan who thinks that mobile phones have stopped us having conversations. And listen out for a phrase that means 'it's unlikely to happen soon'.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Daisy Buchanan, writer for the Telegraph & the Guardian newspapers I was thinking yesterday how it used to be, you know, you used to sort of go into a café or a pub maybe and look for where the loos are but now the first thing we're looking for is sockets to try and find where you can charge if you... you know, if you're having an emergency... And maybe with this, I might be being naïve - I suspect I am - especially with Ikea's new wireless charging furniture... that maybe if our batteries died a bit more frequently we are going to... you know... look up a bit more and have a few more conversations. I'm not holding my breath, but you can but hope.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Daisy said some really interesting things there, so let's listen to that clip again.

transcript.author: <strong>INSERT
transcript.text: INSERT Daisy Buchanan, writer for the Telegraph & the Guardian newspapers I was thinking yesterday how it used to be, you know, you used to sort of go into a café or a pub maybe and look for where the loos are but now the first thing we're looking for is sockets to try and find where you can charge if you... you know, if you're having an emergency... And maybe with this, I might be being naïve - I suspect I am - especially with Ikea's new wireless charging furniture... that maybe if our batteries died a bit more frequently we are going to... you know... look up a bit more and have a few more conversations. I'm not holding my breath, but you can but hope.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Did you get it? Another way of saying 'It's unlikely to happen soon' is I'm not holding my breath . Now, Daisy doesn't seem keen on the idea of wireless charging furniture. She thinks our phones are stopping us from having conversations.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: It sounds ridiculous, but it's true, isn't it? We spend far too much time staring at our phones instead of talking to each other.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Sorry. What's that, Neil? I was just looking at my phone.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Come on, Rob! Put the phone away.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK. Well, that's because phone functionality - that's what a phone can do - is increasing all the time. But let's move on now and think green for a minute. Are there any environmental factors to consider in relation to new mobile phone technology?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Let's listen to Fevzi Turkalp talking about the latest model of one mobile phone brand - and find out.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Fevzi Turkalp, editor of tech advice website GadgetDetective.com They've taken the decision to make it a sealed unit so no user-replaceable battery... And I guess... you're more likely then to say you know what I won't replace the battery I'll just get a new phone.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: So Fevzi says this new phone doesn't have a user-replaceable battery, meaning you can't take it out and replace it - and this is a problem for the environment.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: That's right - environmentalists want products that are designed to be taken apart. Then they can be easily upgraded, repaired or recycled. But you can't do this with a sealed unit - a unit that cannot be opened.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And this means toxic - or poisonous - materials are often dumped in landfill. And you guessed it – that's really bad for the environment. Now, remember at the beginning of the programme I asked you: What do modern phone batteries contain?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And I said lithium...

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And you know your batteries well because that's the right answer!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Wow. What a great guess! Now Rob, how about those words again?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK, the words we heard today were:

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, that brings us to the end of today's 6 Minute English. We hope you're feeling charged up by today's programme. Please join us again soon.

transcript.author: Both
transcript.text: Bye.
